title: 107_s200
content: The "Air Travelers Fair Treatment Act of 2001" ensures fair treatment of airline passengers. The "Air Travelers Fair Treatment Act of 2001" ensures fair treatment of airline passengers by amending Section 41712 of title 49, United States Code to include specific practices that constitute unfair or deceptive practices by air carriers or foreign air carriers. This includes failure to provide accurate explanations for flight delays, cancellations, or diversions, and failure to notify ticket agents of termination or changes in appointment circumstances. The "Air Travelers Fair Treatment Act of 2001" requires airlines to give a 90-day notice with reasons for any action, and 60 days for ticket agents to correct any deficiencies, except in cases of insolvency or bankruptcy. Section 41713(b)(1) of title 49, United States Code, is amended to clarify enforcement of state laws related to air carrier pricing, routes, and service. Additionally, emergency medical assistance and the right of egress are addressed. The Secretary of Transportation will establish regulations for emergency medical care standards on aircraft with at least 30 passengers, considering equipment size, weight, and personnel training. The Secretary of Transportation will establish regulations for emergency medical care standards on aircraft with at least 30 passengers, considering equipment size, weight, personnel training, space limitations, regulations' effects on aircraft operations, airlines' practical experience, and other relevant factors. Before prescribing regulations, consultation with the Surgeon General of the Public Health Service is required. Air carriers cannot prevent passengers from exiting the aircraft under the same circumstances as flight crew members. The regulations allow passengers to exit the aircraft if it has been parked at the gate for over an hour past its scheduled departure time and the captain has not been informed of imminent departure clearance. SEC. 5. CONSUMER ACCESS TO INFORMATION. The new section added to Chapter 447 of title 49, United States Code, requires air carriers to provide written information on safety inspection reviews to passengers upon request. The new section in Chapter 447 of title 49, United States Code, mandates air carriers to furnish safety information to passengers upon request, including safety rankings, crew compliance with certification requirements, and aircraft competency. Guidelines will be provided for air carriers on this information provision. The Secretary must submit an annual report to Congress on the safety of air carriers, including the number and descriptions of accidents attributed to each carrier and the aircraft manufacturers involved. The National Transportation Safety Board will establish a program for victims and survivors of aircraft accidents to provide immediate and unrestricted access to accident information from air carriers, the Federal Government, and State governments. The National Transportation Safety Board, in cooperation with federal agencies and the American Red Cross, will coordinate the disclosure of information and assistance for victims of air commerce accidents. This includes establishing a toll-free telephone line for this purpose. The National Transportation Safety Board, in collaboration with federal agencies and the American Red Cross, will set up a toll-free telephone line to provide information and assistance for victims of air commerce accidents. The Board will ensure the publication of the telephone number in newspapers and on national television news programs. The toll-free telephone line established by the National Transportation Safety Board will provide information on aircraft accidents, victims' names, investigation status, federal agencies, and victim identification facilities. Air carriers failing to comply may face civil penalties up to $100,000. The National Transportation Safety Board established a toll-free telephone line for information on aircraft accidents and victims. Air carriers failing to comply may face civil penalties of up to $100,000 per violation. Travel agencies not providing interstate or foreign air transportation are exempt from these penalties. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the implementation of this section. The Secretary of Transportation must issue regulations for the Air Traveler Safety Program within 90 days of the enactment of the Act. The first annual report to Congress must be submitted by December 31, 2001.
